III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 5/19/23, two youth were at a public pool/hot tub when youth
touched the other youth on the thigh. The next day on 5/20/23,
both youths were the facility when the youth exposed naked body
to the other youth as their doorways were across the hall from
each other. The last incident occurred in the living room area of
the residential facility around two weeks ago when both youths
were sitting on the couch sharing a blanket when youth grabbed
the other youth’s hand and placed it on youth’s genital area and
made youth rub youth. It is unclear if this was consensual.
Investigation Interviews:
Supervisor/Complaint Source was interviewed face to face at
the facility on June 20, 2023. Supervisor reported Youth B gave
her notes that Youth A was writing him about liking him. She
reported that was after Youth A disclosed the allegations within
this special investigation to her on 06/15/2023. Supervisor
reported Youth A did not know the specific dates of the incident on
the couch. Supervisor reported once the disclosure was made,
Youth B was moved to a different home, and peer boundaries
safety plan was put in place for both youth. Prior to these
allegations neither youth had safety plans in place due to
2

sexualized behaviors. Supervisor reported during waking hours
when the youth are in the milieu, they are in the line-of-sight
supervision of staff and if they go to their bedroom then room
checks are completed in varying intervals not exceeding 15
minutes. The same line of sight needs to occur during off-campus
activities. Supervisor reported youth are allowed to have their
personal blankets in the milieu and cannot share their blanket with
another youth. If there are two youth in the milieu with blankets,
they need to have space in between them.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on June
20, 2023, and at the Children’s Advocacy Center on June 26,
2023, in collaboration with Law Enforcement. Youth A reported
she feels safe at the facility and does not have any concerns
about the level of supervision of staff. She reported if she had any
concerns about the way she is being treated by another youth or
staff member she would go to Supervisor. Youth A reported she
likes Youth B and they have touched each other inappropriately
before. She reported that she did not want to discuss anymore
about it. Youth A would not report where or when this touching
occurred but noted it was consensual.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on June
20, 2023, and June 26, 2023. Youth B reported Youth A has
made him feel uncomfortable in the home at times. He reported
Youth A got upset with him because he told her he does not want
to date her. Youth B reported she continued to try to impress him
at times. Youth B reported when he was coming from the
bathroom Youth A was trying to flash him when she was in her
room. He reported he did not want to see anything, so he just
walked away. Youth B reported he never asked Youth A to do
anything for him. He reported that no sexual activity ever
happened with them on any outings or in the milieu area. Youth B
reported he never touched Youth A while in the pool and Staff 2
was supervising the one time they went to the pool together. He
reported staff do a good job at supervising the youth and that
Youth A was being sneaky in her room trying to be inappropriate.
Youth B reported staff do room checks at least every fifteen
minutes or less. He reported he provide notes Youth A was writing
him to Supervisor and that is one of the reasons he had to move
to a different house. Youth B reported youth are allowed to have
their own personal blanket in the milieu, but they cannot share
their blanket with another youth. He reported if two youth have
blankets out in the milieu there has to be at least a couch cushion
of space between them.
3

Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 26,
2023. Staff 1 reported last week Youth A was dropping hints about
liking Youth B and tying to write him notes. Youth B ended up
giving the notes to Supervisor. Then Youth A made the disclosure
of the allegations to Supervisor. Staff 1 reported Youth A and
Youth B just appeared to be close friends on the unit and did not
appear to be in any type of relationship. She reported after the
allegations came to light, Youth B was moved houses and the
youth were put on peer boundaries. Staff 1 reported she has
never seen Youth A or Youth B share a couch with one another
with blankets. She reported youth are allowed to have blankets
but cannot share them and there has to be space between youth.
She reported youth are in line-of-sight supervision of staff and if
they go to their bedroom then room checks are completed in
varying intervals of time not exceeding 15 minutes. The same line
of sight needs to occur during off-campus activities. Staff 1
reported she has never seen poor boundaries between Youth A
and Youth B and never heard those allegations from anyone since
this occurred.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on June 26, 2023. Staff 2
reported he has taken Youth A and Youth B swimming before. He
has never seen anything inappropriate happen at the pool. Staff 2
reported he was in the pool with the youth when they are there so
he can supervise better. He reported he has heard Youth A report
she has a crush on Youth B and he has redirected her when
hearing this. Staff 2 reported the general rule for supervision is
always in line of sight and when youth are in their bedrooms
checks need to be completed in interval checks less than fifteen
minutes. He reported youth can have blankets in the milieu, but
they have to have their own blanket and be spaced apart from
other youth.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face to face at the
facility on June 20, 2023. Chief Administrators reported since the
reported allegations came through, Youth B was immediately
moved to a different home at the facility and both youth were
placed on a peer boundary safety plan. Chief Administrator
reported there has been a review of video footage for the past two
weeks of the milieu area and there has been no footage found to
go along with the allegations. Chief Administrator reported youth
are allowed to have individual blankets when in the milieu and
they cannot share blankets. If two youth have their own blankets
out in the milieu there needs to be a space between the two youth.
4

Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
June 26, 2023. Administrator reported she has been reviewing
video footage of the milieu area to see if there was any time Youth
A and Youth B were on the couch with one another. She reported
she could never find a time of that occurring.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on June
20, 2023. Therapist reported she is assigned to work with Youth
A. She reported Youth A has not disclosed any of these
allegations to her and noted that she was concerned about being
pregnant by someone before being placed at the facility. Youth A
moved to the facility in mid-May 2023. Therapist reported there
were no reported concerns of sexualized behavior of Youth A just
that there was sexual abuse as a child and concerns of self-harm.
Youth A is on a safety plan due to self-harm behaviors. Therapist
reported Youth A has reported to her she is sad Youth B moved
out of the house because he does not get to say good night to
Youth B. She reported Youth A did not elaborate more on that
situation.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 20,
2023. Staff 3 reported she knew Youth A had a crush on Youth B
but never saw any inappropriate behavior occur between the two
youth. She reported she also did not hear any rumors of
inappropriate touch or flashing going on. Staff 3 reported both
Youth A and Youth B were on regular supervision levels prior to
these allegations coming to light. She reported now both youth
need to stay away from one another due to the peer boundary
safety plan. Staff 3 reported if a youth is in their room, interval
room checks need to occur by staff less than fifteen minutes apart.
She reported youth need to be in line of sight when in the milieu
area and if a youth has their personal blanket, they cannot share it
with anyone else and there needs to be space between other
youth.
Youth B’s Foster Care worker was interviewed via phone on
June 16, 2023. She reported when Youth B was first placed at the
facility there were concerns with him being placed with females.
Due to the unit being mostly non-binary youth and youth not
attracted to males, the worker was comfortable with his
placement. Youth B’s Foster Care Worker reported Youth B has
admitted to sexual activity in the past. She reported she has not
had concerns with the facility’s level of care being provided to
Youth B and reported they have been consistent with reporting
concerns to her.
5

Documents Reviewed:
-Notes Given to Supervisor from Youth B- These notes were
not physically reviewed by this consultant due to them being
disposed by Youth B. Within the face-to-face interview with Youth
B he reported he first gave the notes to Supervisor and then
disposed of them. Per the Supervisor and Youth B these notes did
not have any sexual language and were drawing from Youth A to
Youth B with Youth B’s name in a heart.
- Facility Youth Supervision Procedure with the most recent
revision date of June 2022- Staff is responsible for the direct
supervision of youth living in the house in which they are working.
To ensure appropriate supervision, staff responsible for youth
must: maintain visual contact and monitoring of the youth; know
where each youth is at all times; be physically present in close
proximity to the youth; clearly communicate when the supervision
of youth transfers to another staff person; ensure hallways are
being monitored at all times when youth are in their rooms, den,
bathrooms, laundry room, common hallway space or med cart
area. If a staff member must leave their post as the direct
supervisor of the hallway, they will notify another staff to take over
this supervision. For supervision of youth during staff-supervised
off-campus activities, staff are to continue to follow all standard
supervision guidelines.
- Youth A’s Safety Plan dated 05/18/2023- The safety plan was
created due to Youth A having a history of self-injurious behaviors.
It notes staff will complete daily check-ins with Youth A in order to
gauge her current mental state and if there are concerns, a
therapist should be contacted. Staff should check in on Youth A
when they are isolated in their room and encourage them to come
out to do an activity. The safety plan does not note any increased
level of supervision of Youth A.
- Youth A and Youth B’s Peer Boundary Safety Plan dated
06/15/2023- Each youth has a separate safety plan and this was
created due to the allegations of boundary issues. Staff should
stand between and redirect all inappropriate conversations and
boundary concerns with Youth A and Youth B. Both youth should
not be seated next to one another in the house, on outings, or in
vehicles. Each youth must be in the line of sight when in the
milieu.
-Facility Daily Observation Forms for Youth A and Youth B
dated 05/20/2023- Both Youth A and Youth B’s forms were
reviewed by this consultant and staff completed interval checks of
6

both the youth when in their bedrooms no more than 15 minutes.
There were no concerns noted.
-Facility Behavior Observation report for Youth B dated
05/19/2023- Within the report, it does not note any time Youth B
went to the pool with staff and peers that day. He spent the
majority of his time at the facility and went to clean out a van with
staff at one point.
- Facility Daily Observation Forms for Youth A and Youth B
dated 05/21/2023- Both Youth A and Youth B forms note there
was an outing to the pool this day and both youths attended. Staff
2 was the staff to take them to the pool and there were no
reported concerns.
- Email from Law Enforcement dated 06/27/2023- Law
Enforcement reported he closed out his case due to lack of
evidence that anything criminal took place.
-Email from Youth A’s Foster Care Worker dated
06/16/2023- Youth A’s Foster Care worker has not had concerns
with the level of supervision provided by the facility prior to this
incident.
Analysis The facility is found to be in compliance of their supervision policy.
There was no concrete evidence found that the touching occurred
at the pool on 05/19/2023 or touching occurred in the milieu area.
Youth A disclosed an inappropriate touch did occur with Youth B
but would not state where or when it occurred. No video footage
was found to support these claims and Youth B denied touching
Youth A. Staff were all knowledgeable about their supervision
practices and documentation was completed appropriately. The
facility will maintain keeping the two-youth separated for safety
purposes.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
